author: Linnaeus
geographic_range: rocky or shady places, frequently in company with Rocky Mountain cassiope. It is easy to confuse it with the latter plant if the two are not examined closely. The flowers are inconspicuous but the black berries are distinctive. The berries are much eaten by Arctic birds, although rather insipid to the human taste.
specimen_location: Marble Canyon not far from the summit of Vermilion Pass, sixteen miles from Castle Station, Alberta, at an altitude of 5,000 feet
